trial_identification.studytitle: Radiation Exposure and Safety of Lymphatic Mapping and Selective (Sentinel) Lymph Node Biopsy Procedures for Melanoma and Breast Cancer Treatment
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Radiation Exposure and Safety of Lymphatic Mapping and Selective (Sentinel) Lymph Node Biopsy Procedures for Melanoma and Breast Cancer Treatment

interventions.interventions: The aim of the study was to evaluate radiation exposure and safety for staff in the treatment of patients with Early Stage I/II Melanoma and Breast Cancer using Lymphatic Mapping and Selective (Sentinel) Lymph Node Biopsy. This treatment has shown a high degree of safety with very few adverse events. The radiation exposure was studied during surgery and during transport and processing of specimens.

primaryOutcome.outcome: To determine exposure during Selective (Sentinel) Lymph Node Biopsy procedures
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Evaluated during and for 24 hours after the procedures.

primaryOutcome.outcome: To determine safety during Selective (Sentinel) Lymph Node Biopsy procedures
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Evaluated during and for 24 hours after the procedures.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: The secondary outcome was to determine possible associations between procedure duration and handling, exposure level and safety.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Stage I and II cutaneous melanoma > 1mm in Breslow thickness or > Clark Level III; Stage I and II Breast Cancer; Absence of Metastases; Informed Consent.
